docinfo.docinfo:doc-heading: DIVISION 1 DISTRIBUTION BETWEEN COURT OF APPEAL AND DIVISIONS [ss 47–51]

heading.title: DIVISION 1 DISTRIBUTION BETWEEN COURT OF APPEAL AND DIVISIONS [ss 47–51]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: DIVISION 1 DISTRIBUTION BETWEEN COURT OF APPEAL AND DIVISIONS [ss 47–51]

leg:heading.title: DISTRIBUTION BETWEEN COURT OF APPEAL AND DIVISIONS [ss 47–51]

p.text: [s 47 rep Act 41 of 1972 s 5]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 48] s 48 Assignment to the Court of Appeal

leg:heading.title: Assignment to the Court of Appeal

p.text: In this section: specified tribunal means—
the Land and Environment Court or a Judge of that Court;
the Industrial Relations Commission or a member of that Commission;
the Dust Diseases Tribunal of New South Wales;
the Government and Related Employees Appeal Tribunal or a member of the Tribunal who is the Senior Chairman, the Acting Senior Chairman or a Chairman of the Tribunal;
the District Court or a Judge of the District Court;
the Compensation Court of New South Wales;
a judge or a member functioning or purporting to function under any Act giving power to a judge or member, whether as a judge or member or as a designated person;

a body of persons having amongst its number a judge or member, being a body functioning or purporting to function under any Act giving power to a body having amongst its number a judge or member, whether as judge or member or as a designated person but not including the State Parole Authority; or
an Appeal Panel or the Legal Services Division of the Administrative Decisions Tribunal.
In subparagraphs (vi) and (vii) of paragraph (a) judge or member means a judge or member mentioned in any of subparagraphs (i) to (v) inclusive of that paragraph.

[subs (1) am Act 1 of 1975 s 4 ; Act 205 of 1979 s 5 ; Act 46 of 1980 s 3 ; Act 93 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 1 ; Act 153 of 1984 s 5 and Sch 16 ; Act 111 of 1987 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 63 of 1989 s 36 ; Act 34 of 1991 s 752 and Sch 3 ; Act 30 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 17 of 1996 Sch 5 ; Act 94 of 2004 s 4 and Sch 2.7, effective 10 October 2005; Act 98 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 3.49, effective 24 November 2005 ; Act No 77 of 2008 s 4 and Sch 2.7[1], effective 1 January 2009]
There are assigned to the Court of Appeal proceedings in the Court—
[repealed]
for commanding or otherwise requiring a specified tribunal to perform a public duty;
for prohibiting or otherwise restraining a specified tribunal from proceeding in any matter before the tribunal;
for determining, by declaration or otherwise, any matter concerning the powers of a specified tribunal;
on an appeal from a specified tribunal;
for otherwise reviewing a decision of a specified tribunal;
on a case stated by a specified tribunal;
for determining any question of law referred to the Court for its opinion under the Administrative Decisions Tribunal Act 1997,
for the punishment of contempt of Court, but only if the contempt consists of:
contempt in the face of, or in the hearing of, the Court of Appeal, or
disobedience of a judgment or order of the Court of Appeal, or
breach of an undertaking given to the Court of Appeal,
including proceedings in which the Court of Appeal is constituted by an associate Judge,
for such matters as are necessary or convenient for the discharge of the functions of the Court of Appeal; and
for such matters as are prescribed by the rules.
[subs (2) am Act 96 of 1979 s 7 ; Act 111 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1; Act 31 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 13, effective 15 June 2005 ; Act No 77 of 2008 s 4 and Sch 2.7[2], effective 1 January 2009]

Notwithstanding paragraph (d) of subsection (2) the rules may provide for the assignment to the Divisions of the Court of proceedings in the Court for commanding or otherwise requiring the removal into the Court of any matter before a specified tribunal in cases not involving a review of a decision of a specified tribunal.
[subs (4) rep Act 111 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 48.5] Assignment to Court of Appeal

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 48.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 101.
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 SCR Pts 51A, 51B, SCR r 60.17.

For appeals to the Court of Appeal from a judgment or order of the court in a Division see s 101 , and for appeals to the Court of Appeal from certain decisions of an associate judge see SCR r 60.17 . For a summary of provisions assigning business in the court see UCPR [1.16.5] , [45.1.5] . Assignment of business relating to appeals from various courts and tribunals is dealt with in SCR Pts 51A and 51B .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 48.10] Objection to jurisdiction of specified tribunal

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 48.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 48(2)(c), s 69.

heading.title: Objection to jurisdiction of specified tribunal

p.text: Section 48(2)(c) clearly authorises the making of an order restraining a specified tribunal from proceeding to deal with a matter where its jurisdiction has been successfully challenged. But the court has a general discretion whether to make such an order. Where the existence of the appropriate jurisdictional fact cannot properly be determined as a preliminary point the court will not ordinarily interfere until the specified tribunal has finally dealt with the matter unless convenience, urgency or the manifest absence of a lawful basis for the proceedings below require prerogative relief: Boral Gas (NSW) Pty Ltd v Magill (1993) 32 NSWLR 501 ; Metropolitan Water Sewerage and Drainage Board v Judges of the Industrial Commission of New South Wales [1981] AR (NSW) 305 . See also s 69 . A tribunal's decision to exercise jurisdiction amounts to a finding that jurisdiction exists: Tweed Valley Fruit Processor Pty Ltd v Australian Industrial Relations Commission (1996) 137 ALR 70; 65 IR 393

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 48.15] Appeal from, and cases stated by, specified tribunals

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 48.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 section.

heading.title: Appeal from, and cases stated by, specified tribunals

p.text: The present section is concerned only with the assignment of business within the court, it does not confer substantive jurisdiction in relation to either rights of appeal or the power to state a case to the court: Frost v Amaca Pty Ltd [2004] NSWCA 358; BC200406560 at [26]–[29] (Dust Diseases Tribunal has no power to state a case to the Supreme Court). In any particular case the ambit of the court’s jurisdiction depends on the proper construction of the relevant statutory provision: De Pater v CSR Chemicals Ltd [1981] 2 NSWLR 760. Normally the rights of appeal which attract the court’s appellate jurisdiction, whether expressed as a general right of appeal or one limited to questions of law, will relate, or be construed to relate, only to final decisions of the inferior court or tribunal: Bromley v Housing Commission of New South Wales (1985) 3 NSWLR 407 distinguishing Metropolitan Water Sewerage and Drainage Board v Histon [1982] 2 NSWLR 720; unless, perhaps, the decision sought to be appealed from can be regarded as in substance a final decision on a separate or independent part of the case: Blue Mountains City Council v Hudson (1985) 56 LGRA 360 ; Director-General of Social Services v Chaney (1980) 3 ALD 161; 31 ALR 571.
Legislation cited in [SCA s 48.20] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 48(1)(a)(vii), s 48(1)(a)(viii).

A statutory body (other than those specifically listed in the section) whose decision is subject to an appeal is not a “specified tribunal” for the purpose of s 48(1)(a)(vii) merely because its members include a “judge or member”. But if the judicial status of the “judge or member” is relevant to the statutory body’s powers, then it is a "specified tribunal": Daykin v SAS Trustee Corp (2001) 51 NSWLR 328; [2001] NSWSC 58; BC200100561 at [18] (appeal from a decision of the Appeal Panel of the Administrative Decisions Tribunal). On this basis, even before the 2008 amendment of SCA s 48(1)(a)(viii) , an Appeal Panel of the Administrative Decisions Tribunal was held to be a specified tribunal, where the panel included a judge of the District Court: see also Puglisi v Administrative Decisions Tribunal of New South Wales Appeal Panel (2001) 52 NSWLR 350; 116 LGERA 194; [2001] NSWCA 298; BC200105467 . Other appeals from, or proceedings otherwise relating to review of, decisions of the ADT when it is constituted by a “judge or member”, involve decisions of a “specified tribunal and are assigned to the Court of Appeal: Ombudsman v Koopman [2002] NSWSC 1203; BC200208390 .
The following tribunals have been held not to be specified tribunals for the purposes of s 48:
the Legal Aid Commission, in Wentworth v Rogers (No 6) (NSWCA, Kirby P, Glass and Priestley JJA, No 259/86, 10 October 1986, unreported, BC8600638);
the New South Wales Trotting Tribunal, in Hargraves v Trotting Authority of New South Wales (1981) 3 ALN No 34 ;
the Equal Opportunity Tribunal, in Allders International Pty Ltd v Anstee (1986) 5 NSWLR 47; (1986) EOC 92-157; 16 IR 116 ;

the Childrens Court: Director-General, Family and Community Services re Felicity [2012] NSWCA 272; BC201206820 at [19]–[38] (the decision of “Presidential Children’s Court” is a decision of that court and is not a decision of either a “body of persons” or of an individual “judge or member”).
Legislation cited in [SCA s 48.25] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 Section 48(2)(i), (4), s 53(3F), (5).
(NSW) Supreme Court Rules 1970 SCR Pt 55.

Section 48(2)(i) and (4) were amended by the Courts Legislation Amendment Act 1996. As a consequence of the amendment, only contempt in relation to proceedings in the Court of Appeal are now assigned to the Court of Appeal: see s 48(2)(i) . Other contempt proceedings are assigned to the various divisions: see s 53(3F) and (5) . See also Abram v National Australia Bank Ltd (NSWCA, Mason P, Priestley and Powell JJA, No 40487/94, 1 May 1997, unreported, BC9701553) at pp 6–7 per Powell J. (Before the amendment proceedings for the punishment of contempt of the Supreme Court, or of any other court, were, with some exceptions, assigned to the Court of Appeal: see, for example, New South Wales Bar Assn v Muirhead (1988) 14 NSWLR 173 (contempt proceedings in relation to proceedings before a Workers Compensation Commissioner).) The court's powers in relation to contempt generally are dealt with in SCR Pt 55 .
Legislation cited in [SCA s 48.30] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 48(2)(g).

Section 48(2)(g) assigns to the Court of Appeal proceedings for “otherwise reviewing” a decision of a specified tribunal. This imprecise description includes proceedings for a declaration (in connection with criminal proceedings in the District Court) that specific evidence is immune from disclosure: R v Yooyen (1991) 57 A Crim R 226 .

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 48.35] Wrong commencement — effect of s 51(1)(d) of the Supreme Court Act

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 48.35] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 48(2), s 48(2)(g), s 51(1)(b), s 51(1)(d).

heading.title: Wrong commencement — effect of s 51(1)(d) of the Supreme Court Act

p.text: Notwithstanding the provisions of s 48(2) , a division of the court may make a declaration sought under s 48(2)(g) , at least if the other party does not oppose the matter being dealt with in the division. This is so because, subject to s 51(1)(b) , s 51(1)(d) allows proceedings to be continued and disposed of in the division in which they were commenced: Cremona v Shon [1998] NSWSC 390; BC9804078 .

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [SCA s 49] s 49 Assignment to the Divisions

p.text: Subject to Part 7 of this Act, proceedings in the Court which are not assigned to the Court of Appeal are assigned to the Divisions of the Court.
[s 49 subst Act 41 of 1972 s 5]
[s 51 rep Act 41 of 1972 s 5]
Where proceedings are commenced in a Division but are under this or any other Act or under the rules, assigned to the Court of Appeal—
the proceedings shall be for all purposes well commenced on the date of commencement in the Division, notwithstanding that the proceedings are assigned to the Court of Appeal;

the Court of Appeal or the Court in the Division in which the proceedings are pending may, in either case on application by a party or of its own motion, order that the proceedings be removed into the Court of Appeal;
upon an order for removal being made under paragraph (b) the proceedings may be continued and disposed of in the Court of Appeal; and
subject to any order under paragraph (b) the proceedings may be continued and disposed of in a Division.
[subs (1) am Act 41 of 1972 s 5]
Where proceedings are commenced in the Court of Appeal but are under this or any other Act or under the rules, assigned to a Division—
the proceedings shall be for all purposes well commenced on the date of commencement in the Court of Appeal, notwithstanding that the proceedings are assigned to a Division;
the Court of Appeal may, on application by a party or of its own motion, order that the proceedings be remitted to a Division;
upon an order for remission being made under paragraph (b) , the proceedings may be continued and disposed of in a Division; and
subject to any order under paragraph (b) , the proceedings may be continued and disposed of in the Court of Appeal.
[subs (2) am Act 41 of 1972 s 5]
[subs (3) rep Act 41 of 1972 s 5]

Where any proceedings are pending before the Court of Appeal, the Court of Appeal may, on application by a party or of its own motion, order that the whole or any part of the proceedings be remitted to a Division for the determination by trial or otherwise of the proceedings or any question arising in the proceedings.
Where proceedings by way of appeal or otherwise under any Act other than this Act or proceedings on a stated case, other than a case stated by the Court in a Division, are commenced in a Division—

the Court in the Division in which the proceedings are pending, if satisfied that special circumstances exist which render it desirable so to do, may, on application by a party or of its own motion, order that the proceedings be removed into the Court of Appeal; and
upon an order being made under paragraph (a) , the proceedings may be continued and disposed of in the Court of Appeal.
Proceedings may be removed into the Court of Appeal under this section notwithstanding that any decision or determination in the proceedings is expressed by any Act to be final or without appeal.
[subs (6) am Act 41 of 1972 s 5]
None of the foregoing subsections limits the operation of any of the others.
This section does not limit the provision which may be made by the rules for removal or remission of proceedings.

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 51.5] Removal to and remission from the Court of Appeal

p.text: Legislation cited in [SCA s 51.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Uniform Civil Procedure Rules 2005 UCPR r 1.21.
(NSW) Supreme Court Act 1970 s 51(4).

heading.title: Removal to and remission from the Court of Appeal

p.text: Where proceedings have been properly commenced in a Division, the rules both contingently permit the removal of proceedings to the Court of Appeal, and contemplate remission of proceedings back to a Division of the Court: see UCPR r 1.21 . The Court of Appeal has a similar remission power under SCA s 51(4) , even in relation to proceedings pending in that court. Where proceedings have been wrongly commenced in a Division, either the court or the Court of Appeal may order their removal. In the exercise of those discretionary powers, regard may properly be had to the nature and complexity of the issues, as well as the likely costs associated with removal: Satchi & Satchi Aust Pty Ltd v Zeaiter Corporate Holdings Pty Ltd [2008] NSWSC 411; BC200803221 (appeal from specified tribunal ie ADT – assigned to Court of Appeal – removal refused – no question of general importance – likely additional costs of conducting proceedings in the Court of Appeal).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 51.10] Remission by the Court of Appeal

heading.title: Remission by the Court of Appeal

p.text: Proceedings by way of appeal from the court in a division will rarely involve the Court of Appeal exercising the power to remit. Factual issues related to the status of the parties, or to questions of estoppel in respect of issues that were argued in a particular way at first instance, may provide appropriate examples of the exercise of the power: Strata Consolidated (Aust) Pty Ltd v Tannunga Pty Ltd (NSWCA, 13 September 1993, unreported). Where the proceedings in the Court of Appeal arise from proceedings in another court or tribunal the nature of the appeal may influence the appropriateness and desirability of exercising the power to remit. For example, appeals under s 165 of the Legal Profession Act 1987 were by way of a new hearing in the Court of Appeal and where the appeal involved contested issues of fact the determination of those issues was remitted to the Common Law Division of the court: Sedgwick v Law Society of New South Wales (NSWCA, Kirby P, 13 April 1993, unreported, BC9301933).

level.toc-caption: [SCA s 51.15] Consequences of remission — costs of earlier proceedings

heading.title: Consequences of remission — costs of earlier proceedings

p.text: An order remitting proceedings for rehearing in a division may be regarded, at least in the absence of contrary indication, as entitling orders to be made on the rehearing dealing with the costs of the initial hearing, despite the costs orders that were originally made: Knudsen v Kara Kar Holdings Pty Ltd (No 2) (2000) 52 NSWLR 254; [2000] NSWSC 943; BC200006493 ; see further UCPR [42.1.40] .
